entries.name: GPIO_read
entries.description: Reads the digital input value (HIGH or LOW) from a specified GPIO pin using MicroPython.

sections.description:
pin = Pin(pin_name, Pin.IN)
pin_value = pin.value()

pin_name: The GPIO pin identifier (e.g., PORT_A1).
Pin.IN: Configures the pin as an input pin.
Returns 1 if the pin is HIGH and 0 if the pin is LOW.

examples:
from zing import *
from machine import Pin
from time import sleep

A1 = Pin(PORT_A1, Pin.IN)

while True:
    A1_val = A1.value()
    sleep(1)
    print(A1_val)

entries.name: digitalOutput
entries.description: Controls external components connected to a digital output pin. You can set the pin HIGH or LOW to turn devices on or off.

sections.description:
port = Pin(PORT_A1, Pin.OUT)
port.value(1)  # Set HIGH
port.value(0)  # Set LOW

PORT_A1: The external pin where the component is connected.
Pin.OUT: Configures the pin as a digital output.
value: 1 sets HIGH, 0 sets LOW.
No return value. Writing HIGH or LOW to the pin changes the state of the connected external component.

examples:
from zing import PORT_A1, Pin
from time import sleep

port = Pin(PORT_A1, Pin.OUT)

while True:
    port.value(1)  # Turn on
    sleep(1)
    port.value(0)  # Turn off
    sleep(1)

entries.name: ADC_read
entries.description: Reads the analog input value from a specified GPIO pin using MicroPython’s ADC (Analog-to-Digital Converter).

sections.description:
adc = ADC(Pin(pin_name))
adc.atten(ADC.ATTN_11DB)
value = adc.read()

pin_name: The GPIO pin where the analog sensor is connected (e.g., PORT_A1).
ADC.ATTN_11DB: Configures the ADC input range up to 3.3V.
Returns an integer representing the analog input value, typically ranging from 0 to 4095 depending on the board and voltage.

examples:
from zing import PORT_A1, Pin, ADC
from time import sleep

pot = ADC(Pin(PORT_A1))
pot.atten(ADC.ATTN_11DB)       # Full range: 3.3V

while True:
    pot_value = pot.read()
    print(pot_value)
    sleep(0.1)

entries.name: pwmOutput
entries.description: Controls external components (e.g., LEDs, motors) using PWM signals on a specific pin. You can set the duty cycle to control brightness or speed.

sections.description:
pwm = PWM(zing.PORT_A1)
pwm.duty_u16(duty)  # Set PWM duty cycle

PORT_A1: The external pin where the component is connected.
duty: Integer (0–65535) representing the PWM duty cycle. 32768 = 50% duty cycle.
No return value. The function adjusts the PWM signal to control brightness or speed of the connected component.

examples:
import zing
from machine import PWM

pwm = PWM(zing.PORT_A1)
pwm.duty_u16(32768)  # 50% duty cycle

entries.name: readBatteryLevel
entries.description: Reads the battery percentage from the built-in battery sensor on the board. The sensor is onboard with a fixed connection and requires no wiring.

sections.description:
bat = battery()
level = bat.get_level()
battery(): Initializes the built-in battery sensor.
Returns an integer representing the current battery level as a percentage (0–100%).

examples:
from zing import *
from time import sleep

bat = battery()

while True:
    b = bat.get_level()
    print(b)
    sleep(1)

entries.name: readAccelGyro
entries.description: Reads acceleration and gyroscope values from the built-in IMU sensor on the Zing board. The sensor is onboard and does not require any additional wiring.

sections.description:
from zing import IMU
imu = IMU()
acc = imu.get_acc()
gyro = imu.get_gyro()

IMU(): Initializes the onboard IMU sensor.
get_acc(): Reads the accelerometer values.
get_gyro(): Reads the gyroscope values.

get_acc(): Returns a list of three values [ACC_X, ACC_Y, ACC_Z] representing acceleration along the X, Y, and Z axes.
get_gyro(): Returns a list of three values [GYRO_X, GYRO_Y, GYRO_Z] representing angular velocity along the X, Y, and Z axes.

examples:
from zing import IMU

imu = IMU()

while True:
    acc = imu.get_acc()
    gyro = imu.get_gyro()

    print(f"ACC_X={acc[0]}")
    print(f"ACC_Y={acc[1]}")
    print(f"ACC_Z={acc[2]}")

    print(f"GYRO_X={gyro[0]}")
    print(f"GYRO_Y={gyro[1]}")
    print(f"GYRO_Z={gyro[2]}")

entries.name: redRGBUltrasonic
entries.description: Reads distance and controls the built-in RGB LED of the ultrasonic sensor on the Zing board. The module is onboard and does not require additional wiring.

sections.description:
from zing import RGB_Ultrasonic
us = RGB_Ultrasonic()
distance = us.distance_cm()
us.rgb_set_color(red, green, blue)

RGB_Ultrasonic(): Initializes the built-in RGB ultrasonic module.
distance_cm(): Returns the distance to an object in centimeters.
rgb_set_color(red, green, blue): Sets the RGB LED color of the ultrasonic module.
  - red, green, blue: Integers (0–255) representing color intensity.

distance_cm(): Returns a numeric value representing the measured distance in centimeters.
rgb_set_color(): No return value. Changes the color of the onboard RGB LED.

examples:
from zing import RGB_Ultrasonic
from time import sleep

us = RGB_Ultrasonic()

while True:
    dis = us.distance_cm()
    print(dis)
    us.rgb_set_color(255, 0, 0)  # Set RGB LED to red
    sleep(1)

entries.name: readSerialServo
entries.description: Controls and reads data from the built-in serial servo motors on the Zing board. You can read servo position, voltage, and enable or disable torque. The servos are onboard and do not require external wiring.

sections.description:
from zing import SerialServo
servo = SerialServo()
servo.enable_torque(True/False)
pos = servo.read_pos(servo_id)
volt = servo.read_voltage(servo_id)

SerialServo(): Initializes the onboard serial servo controller.
enable_torque(state): Boolean to enable (True) or disable (False) the servo torque.
read_pos(servo_id): Reads the current position of the servo with the given ID.
read_voltage(servo_id): Reads the voltage supplied to the servo with the given ID.

read_pos(): Returns the current angle/position of the specified servo.
read_voltage(): Returns the current voltage of the specified servo.
enable_torque(): No return value. Enables or disables torque for the servo.

examples:
from zing import SerialServo
from time import sleep

servo = SerialServo()
servo.enable_torque(False)  # Disable torque

for _ in range(2):
    pos1 = servo.read_pos(1)
    volt1 = servo.read_voltage(1)
    print('Position:', pos1)
    print('Voltage:', volt1)
    sleep(2)

servo.enable_torque(True)  # Enable torque

entries.name: rgbLED
entries.description: Controls the built-in RGB LEDs on the Zing board. Each LED can be set individually with red, green, and blue intensity values.

sections.description:
from zing import rgb_led
led = rgb_led()
led.set_pixels(num, red, green, blue)
led.update_pixels()

num: Integer indicating which RGB LED to control(1 to 4).
red, green, blue: Integers (0–255) representing the intensity of each color channel.
rgb_led(): Initializes the onboard RGB LED controller.
No return value. The color of the specified RGB LED is updated when update_pixels() is called.

examples:
from zing import rgb_led

led = rgb_led()
led.set_pixels(1, 255, 0, 0)  # Set first LED to red
led.update_pixels()

entries.name: serialServoOutput
entries.description: Controls the built-in serial servo motors on the Zing board as output. You can move the servo to a specific angle over a specified duration. The servos are onboard and do not require external wiring.

sections.description:
from zing import SerialServo
servo = SerialServo()
servo.move(servo_id, angle, duration_ms)

SerialServo(): Initializes the onboard serial servo controller.
servo_id: Integer representing which servo to control.
angle: Target angle/position to move the servo to.
duration_ms: Time in milliseconds to complete the movement.
No return value. Moves the specified servo to the target angle over the given duration.

examples:
from zing import SerialServo
from time import sleep

servo = SerialServo()

while True:
    servo.move(1, 100, 1000)  # Move servo 1 to 100 degrees in 1 second
    sleep(1)
    servo.move(1, 1024, 1000) # Move servo 1 to 1024 position in 1 second
    sleep(1)

entries.name: servoOutput
entries.description: Controls an external servo motor connected to the board using PWM signals. The servo can be rotated to a specific angle between 0° and 180° by generating the appropriate PWM signal on the external port.

sections.description:
import zing
from machine import Pin, PWM
import time

servo = PWM(Pin(zing.PORT_A1))
servo.freq(50)

# Define a helper function to move the servo
def move_servo(angle):
    min_pulse = 0.5
    max_pulse = 2.5
    pulse = min_pulse + (angle / 180) * (max_pulse - min_pulse)
    duty = int((pulse / 20) * 65535)
    servo.duty_u16(duty)

PORT_A1: The port where the external servo is connected.
angle: The angle to rotate the servo to, in degrees (0–180).
move_servo(angle): Moves the external servo to the specified angle by converting the angle into the appropriate PWM duty cycle.
No return value. The connected external servo motor physically rotates to the specified angle.

examples:
import zing
from machine import Pin, PWM
import time

servo = PWM(Pin(zing.PORT_A1))
servo.freq(50)

def move_servo(angle):
    min_pulse = 0.5
    max_pulse = 2.5
    pulse = min_pulse + (angle / 180) * (max_pulse - min_pulse)
    duty = int((pulse / 20) * 65535)
    servo.duty_u16(duty)

try:
    while True:
        for angle in range(0, 181, 10):
            move_servo(angle)
            time.sleep(0.01)
        for angle in range(180, -1, -10):
            move_servo(angle)
            time.sleep(0.01)
except KeyboardInterrupt:
    servo.deinit()  # Stop PWM when interrupted

entries.name: sleep
entries.description: Pauses the execution of the program for a specified number of seconds. Useful for creating delays between actions.

sections.description:
from time import sleep
sleep(seconds)
seconds: A number representing the amount of time to pause the program. Can be an integer or a float (e.g., 1 for 1 second, 0.1 for 100 milliseconds).
No return value. The program simply waits for the specified duration before continuing execution.

examples:
from time import sleep

print('Start')
sleep(1)  # Wait for 1 second
print('End')

entries.description: Holds the current status of a digital pin.

sections.description: int
0 (LOW) or 1 (HIGH)
